The museum specializes in the lifestyle of the Tornio Valley and border phenomena. It is located in the center of Tornio, next to the library and Aine Art Museum.

The museum's exhibits bring the past to life using artifacts, images, and film. It highlights the unique aspects of life in the border region. In 2014, it became the world's only cross-border museum, with operations funded also by the municipality of Haparanda, Sweden. Besides the permanent exhibition, the museum hosts 2-5 temporary exhibitions every year.

name: Turjanlinna
description: Turjanlinna is closely associated with the author Ilmari Kianto. It was his wilderness home where he experienced great dramas, victories, and losses in his life. The original Turjanlinna was destroyed in a fire during the Winter War in 1939. However, some buildings in the courtyard have been preserved to this day and serve as an open-air museum in the summer. Kianto wrote over 60 works, most famously about the lives of poor people in Kainuu. In summer, it's possible to visit Turjanlinna by boat.

name: Turkansaaren ulkomuseo
description:
Turkansaari Open-Air Museum, located on three islands in Oulu, is the second oldest open-air museum in Finland, founded in 1925. It showcases traditional rural life in Northern Ostrobothnia. Visitors can explore over 40 buildings that were relocated to the island, including a church from 1694.

The museum highlights agriculture, forestry, fishing, and tar production. Throughout the summer, the museum hosts events like Midsummer celebrations and tar burning week, offering demonstrations of old-time skills. Visitors can experience the history of the Oulujoki river valley, including salmon fishing and forestry. The museum provides insight into peasant construction and culture in Northern Finland.

name: Turun linna
description:
Turku Castle, located at the mouth of the Aura River in Turku, is a medieval castle founded in the 1280s. It was initially established as an administrative castle for the Swedish Crown but later transformed into a Renaissance castle during the reign of Duke John III, a residence for the Governor-General of Finland, and even a prison.

Since the late 19th century, the castle has served as a museum, though it suffered significant damage during Soviet air raids in the summer of 1941. Extensive repairs and restoration work were carried out after World War II. Today, Turku Castle is one of Finland's most important architectural and historical monuments, and a major tourist attraction. Its facilities are used by the Turku City Historical Museum, and the castle church is a popular wedding venue.

name: Turun museokeskus
description: Turku Museum Centre encompasses several museums in Turku, each offering a unique glimpse into different facets of history, art, and culture. These include Turku Castle, a medieval fortress showcasing centuries of Finnish history. The Turku City Art Museum WAM, which displays contemporary local and international art but will be closed for renovation from May 2024 to September 2026, with exhibitions continuing in the WAM Kilta Gallery. The Biological Museum presents Finnish nature through dioramas. Other notable locations are Pharmacy Museum and the Qwensel house, Luostarinmäki, and Kylämäki Village.

name: Turun taidemuseo
description:
The Turku Art Museum is one of Finland's most significant art museums. Exhibitions introduce visitors to the world of art, from classics to the latest contemporary art.

The museum is housed in a striking, national romantic granite building designed by Professor Gustaf Nyström. It was the second building in Finland specifically designed as an art museum. The museum's collections include Finnish art from the 19th and 20th centuries, as well as international art.

Currently, the exhibitions include "MIKÄ VÄRI. Kokoelma", "KOLME KATSETTA MAISEMAAN. Holmberg - Munsterhjelm - Westerholm", "AXEL STRASCHNOY. Kohti avaruutta", and "ARTTU NIEMINEN. Lift Up Your Voices".

name: Turun tuomiokirkkomuseo
description: Located in the south gallery of Turku Cathedral, the Turku Cathedral Museum takes you on a journey back to the 14th century. The museum's collection tells the story of the cathedral's history and church life, showcasing religious artifacts from the Catholic Middle Ages, including sculptures of saints and altar equipment. Post-Reformation items include church textiles and silverware. The museum also illustrates the various stages of the cathedral's construction. It is open daily from 9 am to 6 pm, except during church services, and an entrance fee is required.

name: Turun yliopiston eläinmuseo
description:
The Zoological Museum of the University of Turku is a natural history museum located in Turku. It is part of the Biodiversity Unit of the Faculty of Mathematics and Natural Sciences at the University of Turku. The museum maintains and develops the second largest natural science collections in Finland, with a total of almost 4 million samples. These collections form long time series dating from the 1800s to the present day.

The collections consist of scientific collections for research, as well as study and public collections, containing a majority of domestic mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, and fish. There is also a comprehensive collection of domestic insects and some tropical animals. The museum's collections include thousands of scientific animal specimens from Alaska, Amazonia, the Seychelles, the Canadian Arctic, Siberia, the Pacific Islands, Vietnam, and the Mediterranean.

name: Tuusulan työläiskotimuseo
description:
The Tuusula Workers' Home Museum is a small but interesting museum located on a hill near the Tuusula Church. It showcases the life of two craftsmen, a shoemaker and a carpenter, in the early 1900s. The museum depicts a home frozen in time, specifically the 1930s. The shoemaker, who lived as a bachelor, shared a room with his apprentice, while the carpenter and his family lived on the other side of the house in a home consisting of a kitchen and one room.

The museum's yard also features a blacksmith's workshop and changing exhibitions. It tells the story of rural craftsmen's lives in the early 20th century.

name: Tyrnävän kotiseutumuseo
description:
Tyrnävän kotiseutumuseo is a local museum in the municipality of Tyrnävä, Northern Ostrobothnia. The museum focuses on the agricultural history of the region. It comprises 14 buildings, the oldest of which dates back to the 1760s. The construction of the museum area began in 1967, and it is maintained through volunteer work.

The museum grounds include an agricultural machinery museum hall, the Tihinen house (a traditional smokehouse), Kesti's storehouse, a smoke sauna, a smithy, three granaries, the Männikkö barn, a shingle planer, a woodshed, a well, and a milk platform. Also, there is the agricultural machinery museum and an old granary which is located near the church of Tyrnävä and serves as a museum of objects.

name: Tytyrin kaivosmuseo
description:
The Tytyri Mine Museum is located in Lohja, approximately 80 meters underground within the Tytyri Mine. The museum showcases the history of mining operations, with a permanent exhibition dedicated to the topic. In addition to the mining history displays, the mine also hosts rotating art exhibitions and light shows.

The Tytyri Experience Mine also includes a geological exhibition and the Troll Cave, a themed area for families. The mine has an event space called the Tytyri-sali, available for private events. The Kone company uses the mineshaft to test new elevator models. Visitors can explore the mine independently during opening hours or take a guided tour. The Tytyri Mine Museum was opened in May 1988.

name: Työväenasuntomuseo
description:
The Työväenasuntomuseo, or Workers' Housing Museum, is located in Alppila, Helsinki. It offers a glimpse into the everyday lives of working-class families in Helsinki during the 20th century.

Housed in one of the oldest wooden buildings constructed for workers in 1909, the museum features nine small apartments, each decorated to represent different eras. Visitors can observe the evolution of living conditions as gramophones, spring mattresses, and electric lamps gradually appeared in the homes. Note that the museum is currently closed for renovations until the summer of 2025.

name: Työväenmuseo Werstas
description: The Finnish Labour Museum Werstas is located in Tampere, within the historic Finlayson factory area. It specializes in Finnish social history, focusing on the history of work and workers. The museum's exhibitions cover working-class history from the 19th century to the present day. At the Industry Museum exhibition, you can view pictures of 1860s Tampere, play a game to find out how you would have earned a living in a factory a hundred years ago. Additionally, the Steam Engine Museum features a majestic Sulzer steam engine used in the Finlayson cotton mill in the early 20th century. Admission to the museum is free.

name: Urajärven kartano
description:
Urajärvi Manor, located in Asikkala, is a historically significant manor house that now operates as a museum. For nearly 250 years, it belonged to the von Heideman family. The last family members, siblings Lilly and Hugo von Heideman, bequeathed the manor to be maintained as a museum. The manor museum opened to the public in 1928 and is one of the oldest manor museums in Finland.

The main building showcases an Empire style, with the interior reflecting the early 1900s home of Lilly and Hugo von Heideman. A side building was transformed by the siblings into a museum during their lifetime, called "the quiet house of memories". The estate also features the charming Hugo's Path, leading to Valhalla, an observation point with a semi-circular colonnade built in 1913 in the antique style.

In recent years, the manor faced closure due to budget cuts, but was saved by the efforts of local villagers who formed the "Friends of Urajärvi Manor" association to ensure its continued operation as a museum.

name: Urheilun ja liikunnan kulttuurikeskus Tahto
description:
The Urheilun ja liikunnan kulttuurikeskus Tahto, formerly known as the Urheilumuseo (Sports Museum), is a specialized museum dedicated to sports and physical culture. It is located in the Helsinki Olympic Stadium and serves as Finland's national museum with this specific focus.

Tahto's sports archive functions as the primary national archive. It also houses one of the most extensive libraries in the world related to sports and physical activity. The museum's main exhibition showcases the grand narrative of Finnish sports, appealing to all senses. It features diverse and unique audiovisual content that immerses visitors in the atmosphere of the Helsinki Olympics, among other things.

name: Uudenkaupungin automuseo
description:
The Uusikaupunki Automobile Museum is considered one of the most significant automobile museums in Finland and a popular year-round destination. It is located next to the Valmet Automotive car factory.

The museum has three exhibition halls with an extensive collection of classic cars and exhibits related to motoring and motorsports. Besides cars, there are also motorcycles and even two airplanes on display. The collection features a wide range of car models, including the first Finnish car, the Korvensuu from 1913, and a collection of concept cars showcasing futuristic designs by Finnish car designers. There is also a section dedicated to the Saab brand and other Finnish cars.

name: Vakoilumuseo
description:
The Spy Museum, Vakoilumuseo, is the first museum dedicated to espionage. It was established in Tampere in 1998. The museum showcases a variety of spy gadgets and tools, including concealed microphones, miniature cameras, and code devices.

Visitors can explore the world of espionage through interactive exhibits. They can also learn about famous spies and their methods. The museum offers a fun "Agent Test" where visitors can test their spy skills and receive a diploma. It is located in the Finlayson area.

name: Vallilan siirtolapuutarhamuseo
description:
The Vallilan siirtolapuutarhamuseo (Vallila Allotment Garden Museum) is located in Helsinki's Vallilanlaakso, specifically on Mansikkapolku within the Vallila allotment garden. It is one of Finland's smallest museums. The museum is housed in the only original cottage from 1932 in the area, designed by architect Birger Brunila and Väinö Tuukkanen.

Besides the approximately 10 square meter cottage, the museum also includes the surrounding yard, which was restored between 2009 and 2010 to reflect the model plans from the 1930s. Today, the museum plot showcases many useful and ornamental plants from the 1930s. The Vallila allotment garden, consisting of 174 plots, was established in 1932, making it the third oldest in Helsinki and is protected by the town plan.

name: Valvillan tehdasmuseo
description:
The Valvilla Factory Museum is located in Hyvinkää, in the park area of the old wool factory. It showcases the nearly 100-year history of the wool spinning mill founded in 1892 by engineer Ossian Donner and its growth into one of Finland's largest and most diverse textile factories.

The museum displays machines that evoke nostalgia, products manufactured by the wool mill, and photographs depicting the daily life and workers of the factory halls. The museum also highlights Hyvinkää's local history and the development of the town, which grew around the factory.

name: Vankilamuseo
description:
The Vankila Prison Museum, located in Hämeenlinna, is Finland's largest prison museum. It's situated next to the Häme Castle. This former county prison of Hämeenlinna, which was Finland's first cell prison, was built in 1871. The prison ceased operations in 1993 and opened as a museum in 1997.

The museum displays the history of the Finnish prison system and prison life. It evokes emotions and invites visitors to contemplate fundamental questions about humanity. The past comes alive through the writings on the walls, objects, and the cells.

name: Vantaan kaupunginmuseo
description:
The Vantaa City Museum is maintained by the city of Vantaa. Its main location is in the old Tikkurila railway station, which was built in 1862. The museum focuses on the history, cultural heritage, and cultural environment of Vantaa. It provides a learning environment for residents of all ages and offers educational services like guided tours and workshops for schools and daycares.

The museum's collections include various items like objects, photographs, archival and audiovisual material, newspaper cuttings, and a reference library. The museum researches and documents Vantaa's history and cultural environment. The museum also has exhibition and event activities at Håkansböle Manor. Admission to the museum is free.

name: Vantaan maatalousmuseo
description:
Vantaa Agricultural Museum, located in Vantaanlaakso, offers visitors a nostalgic journey into the colorful history of the old Helsinki parish. The museum's objects and glimpses into people's everyday lives vividly depict the former way of life in the old agricultural parish.

The museum is owned by the association "Helsinge Lantmannagille r.f. Vanda", founded in 1882. The museum is bilingual. It is open during the summer season on Sundays and by appointment at other times. The museum has two buildings, Emil and Maiju, which have meeting rooms suitable for about 50 and 100 people. The premises are rented out for meetings and parties. Small concerts and public events have also been organized in the museum premises.

name: Vantaan taidemuseo Artsi
description:
Vantaa Art Museum Artsi is a museum of contemporary art located in Myyrmäki, Vantaa. Specifically, it resides within the Myyrmäkitalo, a cultural and multi-purpose center. Artsi showcases changing exhibitions of contemporary art and also presents works from Vantaa's extensive art collection.

Since 2016, Artsi has specialized not only in contemporary art but also in street art, graffiti, and performance art. Artsi also maintains Galleria K in Tikkurila which is a joint exhibition space. The museum is known as a learning environment and a discussion forum for diverse phenomena of contemporary art. Entrance to Artsi is free.

name: Varalan liikuntamuseo
description:
Varalan liikuntamuseo is a sports museum located in Tampere, within the Varala Sports Institute. It resides in a villa built in 1892 by Henrik Liljeroos and designed by Karl Snellman.

The museum was founded by a private association and was realized through volunteer work, opening on June 6, 1971.

Its collections showcase the history of women's gymnastics, featuring equipment, costumes, and photographs. A notable item is the ski suit donated by Lydia Wideman-Lehtonen, worn when she won the 10 km race at the 1952 Oslo Olympics. The museum building itself is the oldest within the Varala Sports Institute.

name: Varsamäen hevosajoneuvomuseo
description: Varsamäki Horse Carriage Museum is the largest horse carriage museum in Finland, though relatively unknown. The museum's collection has been gathered and is maintained by the owning family. It is located in the attic of the Varsamäki stable, which was established as a horse breeding farm. The basic collection comes from Liuksiala Manor, but it has been expanded with donations from Kangasala farms, the Kangasala parish, and private donors. Each carriage, cart, and sleigh has its own story. The museum's collection is nationally valued. The oldest carriage is Captain Otto Meurman's travel carriage from the early 1800s. The carriages are excellent examples of the craftsmanship of their time. The museum is open by appointment for both private individuals and groups.

name: Vehmaan museot
description:
The Vehmaa museums are located at Mynämäentie 157, Vinkkilä. This interesting site lies along the historic Great Post Route, opened in the 1630s. In the summer, the museums are open on weekends from 12 to 4 PM, and at other times by appointment.

The museum area includes the Vehmaa Local History Museum, housed in the former main building of the Huolila estate, built in the 1800s. There's also the unique Stone Industry Museum, focused on the local stone industry, and a croft of a soldier from the 1700s. Additionally, there is the old fire station of Lahdinko with an exhibition focusing on the old fire brigade activities. There is also a new museum site in Vehmaa in the former stone industry area of Vinkkilä: The Sa-Int National Defence Museum.

name: Vehoniemen automuseo
description: Vehoniemen Automuseo is located in Kangasala, about 25 kilometers from Tampere, near the Kaivanto canal. Founded in 1983 by Lilja and Olavi Sallinen, the museum showcases a diverse collection of vintage and classic cars and motorcycles. The museum resides in the Vehoniemi Ridge Nature Reserve, a popular destination since the 1920s, and is near the Vehoniemi observation tower, offering scenic views. The museum also includes a toy shop and a cafe. The museum's exhibitions often have themes, such as Japanese cars and motorcycles, and the displays change frequently, with individual vehicles rotated every few weeks during the summer.

name: Veturimuseo
description:
The Veturimuseo, or Locomotive Museum, is located in Toijala, Akaa, near the Toijala railway station. The museum is run by Museoveturiseura ry and is open daily during the summer months, and at other times by appointment. The museum showcases the importance of Finnish locomotive industry and train traffic to Finland.

On display are 13 restored locomotives, photographs, drawings, models, and related artifacts. The museum features old diesel locomotives, a couple of steam locomotives, and a Valmet-made rail bus called "Lättähattu". The museum provides guided tours and also has a summer cafe.

name: Villa Aalto
description:
Villa Aalto, located in Helsinki, was designed by architects Aino and Alvar Aalto. Completed in 1936, it served as both their family home and a working studio. The building's design cleverly separates the living spaces from the studio area. The living areas feature cozy interiors, furnished mainly with pieces designed by the Aaltos. In contrast, the studio is a spacious and functional area with tall ceilings.

Alvar Aalto lived in the house until his death in 1976. Recognizing the building's cultural significance, the Finnish government renovated it in 2000 and opened it to the public as a museum. The villa showcases "romantic functionalism," merging a family home with an architect's workplace. The house's design includes natural materials and carefully considered room orientations to maximize natural light.

name: Villa Gyllenberg
description:
Villa Gyllenberg is a private art museum located on the island of Kuusisaari in Helsinki. It was once the home of Signe and Ane Gyllenberg, who were passionate art collectors. The museum showcases their extensive collection, featuring Finnish and international art from the 16th to the 20th centuries.

The villa itself was built in 1938 and later expanded with a gallery wing. The collection includes works by renowned artists such as Helene Schjerfbeck and Akseli Gallen-Kallela. Besides the permanent collection, the gallery hosts temporary exhibitions and concerts. There is also a café in the museum. The Didrichsen Art Museum is located nearby.

name: Villa Kokkonen
description:
Villa Kokkonen, located in Järvenpää near Lake Tuusula, is a unique home designed by Alvar Aalto for the composer Joonas Kokkonen and completed in 1969. It's one of the few private residences Aalto designed. The house is characterized by its fan-like shape and is divided into three main sections. These include living and dining areas, a study centered around a grand piano, and private quarters.

The design centers around a spacious, soundproofed music studio, reflecting the home's purpose as both a residence and a workspace for the composer. The interior features custom-made furniture by Artek and Aalto himself. The building blends into the landscape, and its facade has a wavy shape, which is reminiscent of the lid of a grand piano.

name: Visavuori
description:
Visavuori is a museum located in Valkeakoski. It is dedicated to the life and work of sculptor Emil Wikström and his grandson, the cartoonist Kari Suomalainen. The museum complex consists of three buildings: Emil Wikström's home, his studio, and Kari's Pavilion.

Wikström's home offers a glimpse into the life of the artist, showcasing the Nordic style of the time with many "art nouveau" details. His studio displays almost 100 of his works. Kari's Pavilion hosts exhibitions of Suomalainen's political cartoons and also features works by other artists. In the summer, visitors can arrive by boat, and combine museum visit with cruise. The museum also has a café.

name: Vuolukivimuseo
description: The Vuolukivimuseo, or Soapstone Museum, is located in Nunnalahti, Juuka. The museum showcases the history of soapstone mining and processing in the area. Through photographs and exhibits, visitors can learn about the traditional methods used to extract and work with soapstone. The museum displays a variety of tools, ranging from picks to drills and stone transport carts, that were used in the mining and processing of soapstone. Each year, the museum features different themed exhibitions, and it has a permanent exhibit displaying soapstone ovens, showcasing how the ancient stone continues to be used today.

name: Willa MAC
description:
Willa MAC was a private art museum located in Pyynikinrinne, Tampere. Raija Weckman and Antti Salovaara founded it in 2001. The museum and its gallery operated until the end of 2012, focusing on Finnish contemporary art.

The building, resembling an Italian palazzo, was built in the 1920s for pharmacist Severi Haapanen and designed by Veikko Kallio. Willa MAC operated in Haapanen's villa on Palomäentie, rented from the city of Tampere, which previously housed the Tampere Museum of Contemporary Art. The building's condition deteriorated in the 2010s, making it unsuitable for exhibitions.

name: Wolkoffin talomuseo
description:
The Wolkoff House Museum in Lappeenranta is one of the oldest preserved wooden buildings in the city, with parts dating from 1826 to 1905. Originally built by businessman Jacob Claudelin, the house was later home to the Wolkoff family for four generations, from 1872 to 1983. The family, originally from Russia, made their living as merchants.

In 1986, the heirs of the Wolkoff family donated the house to be used as a museum, which opened in 1993. The interiors reflect a unique combination of styles accumulated over the years. The museum is only accessible through guided tours, which start at the former shop, now a museum gift shop. During the tour, visitors can explore the beautifully preserved rooms filled with original furnishings and artifacts that tell the story of the family.

name: Wäinö Aaltosen museo
description:
The Wäinö Aaltonen Museum of Art (WAM) is an art museum located in Turku, Finland, dedicated to modern art. Situated on the east bank of the Aura River, its permanent exhibition showcases the City of Turku's art collection, with a focus on works by Finnish artist and sculptor Wäinö Aaltonen. The museum also hosts temporary exhibitions of Finnish and international modern art.

The modernist building was designed by Matti and Irma Aaltonen and opened in 1967. Inside, you can find a cafeteria and a shop. The museum plays an active role in organizing diverse activities like concerts and museum pedagogical events. Currently, the museum is undergoing renovations that started in June 2024 and are expected to be completed in the autumn of 2026. During this time, Kilta Galleria at the Arts House serves as WAM's temporary location.

name: Yli-Lauroselan talomuseo
description:
Yli-Laurosela House Museum, located in Ilmajoki, showcases South Ostrobothnian peasant and building culture from its heyday in the 1800s. Visitors can explore traditional Ostrobothnian life within the museum's charming setting. The main building, completed in 1848, exemplifies wealthy Ostrobothnian farmhouses, blending local building traditions with Empire style influences.

The museum complex includes nine outbuildings, such as a smithy, sauna, and stable. The farmstead came under state ownership in 1971 and opened as a museum in 1978. The main building's rooms are furnished with local artifacts, some original to the house. There is also a museum cafe.

name: Ylämyllyn Wanha Automuseo
description:
Ylämyllyn Wanha Automuseo, also known as Pohjois-Karjalan Automuseo, is located in Ylämylly, Liperi. It's run by the Pohjois-Karjalan Automobiilikerho, a group of local car enthusiasts. The museum showcases vehicles primarily owned by members of the car club.

The collection features dozens of cars from various eras, including a rare 1911 Opel Torpedo. Besides cars, you can find motorcycles, mopeds, tractors, and trucks. The museum displays vehicles driven on the roads of North Karelia throughout the years. The club arranges Susirajan Rompepäivät, swap meet, every May.

name: Äänekosken taidemuseo
description: The Äänekoski Art Museum is located in a beautiful log house built in 1900 in the "dragon style". The museum is located in Klubinmäki, a protected park area with valuable cultural heritage and old buildings. The museum's basic exhibition is compiled from the collection of the Toivo Parantainen Art Museum Foundation. The collection includes works by Wäinö Aaltonen, H. Ahtela, Hugo Simberg, Essi Renvall, Simo Hannula and Veikko Vionoja. The museum also organises several changing exhibitions throughout the year, featuring works by local artists. The building itself, known as the Hammarén House, was originally built as a residence for the manager of the factory.

name: Suomen kansallismuseo
description: The National Museum of Finland, located in the heart of Helsinki, presents Finnish history from the Stone Age to the present day through objects and cultural history. The building itself, completed in 1910 and opened in 1916, is considered a masterpiece of the Finnish National Romantic style. Currently, the museum is undergoing a major renovation and expansion project, with reopening tentatively scheduled for 2027. The museum is part of the Finnish Heritage Agency and showcases diverse collections illustrating Finnish folk culture, world cultures, and the culture of Finno-Ugric peoples.
